notes.limitations: We can only review the test results and doctor notes that were provided to us. If you have had other tests, visits, or treatments not included in these records, this decision aid may be missing important information.
notes.disclaimer: This is not medical advice. Before making any medical decisions: Always consult with your healthcare team. Make sure your doctors have all of your complete medical records and test results. Discuss any questions or concerns about this decision aid with your oncologist.

fields.diagnosis_summary: Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) is the most common type of breast cancer. In simple terms, it started in the milk ducts (DCIS) and has now grown slightly outside of the ducts (IDC).

tumors.title: Tumor 1
tumors.notes: The tumor is small —less than a centimeter, or about the size of a dime. Grade 2 is considered intermediate —not the slowest, but also not the fastest or most aggressive. Initial tests show no signs of spread to the lymph nodes.

whatThisMeans.goodNews: The tumor is small, and initial tests show no signs of spread to the lymph nodes, which is a positive sign for a successful outcome.
whatThisMeans.newOptions: A critical step in determining your course of treatment will likely come from something called the Oncotype DX score. This score will be the key piece of information that helps you and your Medical Oncologist decide if you can safely avoid chemotherapy.
whatThisMeans.treatmentFocus: The primary, highly effective long-term treatment will be anti-hormone pills (endocrine therapy) to 'starve' the cancer and keep it from returning for years, because your cancer is hormone receptor positive.
whatThisMeans.otherConsiderations: Your HER2 status suggests that your cancer does not overproduce the HER2 protein. This suggests you will not need the specific, targeted medications designed for HER2-positive cancer.

source.report_name: Biopsy, Breast, w/ Ultrasound Guidance (Proc) (Left Breast)

items.name: Germline genetic testing
items.explanation: Blood test to check for inherited cancer gene changes (like BRCA1/BRCA2).

items.name: Oncotype DX
items.explanation: Genetic test of the tumor to predict recurrence risk and whether chemotherapy would be beneficial. This is typically a test done using samples taken from the surgical removal of any tumor.

items.name: Referral to Radiation Oncology
items.explanation: Recommended after breast surgery if breast conserving surgery is performed.

fields.summary: While your treatment plan will vary depending on the results of some of the tests and scans that need to be done, we have put together the most likely scenario based on what we know from your Medical Records as of 11/02/2025.

treatments.name: Endocrine therapy (hormone therapy)
treatments.description: Most likely treatment given that you are hormone receptor positive (ER+ and PR+).
treatments.expected_timing: Typically started by the medical oncologist after surgery.

medications.name: Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERM)
medications.description: Like tamoxifen — pills that block estrogen.

treatment_time.notes: Administered orally and continued long term depending on response.

treatments.name: Surgical Oncology
treatments.description: Surgery is likely required to fully remove the invasive ductal carcinoma (8mm) and associated DCIS.

treatment_time.notes: The pros and cons of Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy will be a valuable conversation to have with your surgeon.

treatments.name: Chemotherapy
treatments.description: This might be considered a part of your therapy regimen and will be dependent on the Oncotype DX score.

treatments.name: Radiation Oncology
treatments.description: This might be recommended if you and your surgeon choose a Lumpectomy (Breast-Conserving Surgery).

treatments.name: Ovarian suppression
treatments.description: For premenopausal patients, ovarian suppression may be added to endocrine therapy as an alternative to chemotherapy depending on the Oncotype DX score result.

treatment_time.notes: This is often given via monthly injections to temporarily or permanently stop ovarian function, significantly improving treatment effectiveness.

sections.title: Helpful Questions for Your Oncologist
sections.description: Prompts to guide your next oncology visit.

questions.text: Given my specific tumor status ($	ext{HR}+/	ext{HER}2-$), how soon can the OncotypeDX test be ordered, and when can we expect the results? How will this single score determine my need for chemotherapy?
I am currently taking an Estrogen Patch and Progesterone Pill. Since my cancer is hormone receptor positive, what is the immediate risk of continuing this, and when exactly should I stop taking?

What specific anti-hormone medication (e.g., Tamoxifen or an Aromatase Inhibitor) do you recommend, and for how many years will I need to take it? What are the most common side effects of this medication?
If my OncotypeDX score is high, what chemotherapy regimen would you recommend, and how many cycles would that involve?
Since I am premenopausal and my treatment will include endocrine therapy, what is the impact on my future fertility, and should I meet with the fertility counselor immediately?
What is the likelihood of experiencing specific side effects, like hair loss, weight changes, or joint pain, with the systemic treatment you anticipate recommending?
What support services or medications are available here at the clinic for managing fatigue, hot flashes, or any emotional concerns related to my diagnosis and treatment?
Given my tumor size (8 mm) and clear margins, am I a good candidate for Breast-Conserving Surgery (Lumpectomy)? What factors might require me to have a mastectomy instead?
My initial ultrasound was negative for lymph node involvement. Will I still need a Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) during the surgery, and what happens if cancer is found in those nodes?
What is your goal for clear margins, and what is the chance I would need a second surgery to clear them (a re-excision)?
What is the typical recovery time after a lumpectomy or mastectomy? When can I resume normal activities like running and walking my dog (as noted in my history)?
What will the breast look like after surgery, and will a plastic surgeon be involved in my care?
Who is the best point person on your team (e.g., a nurse navigator) for scheduling, pre-op instructions, and answering questions right after surgery?

categories.name: Questions for the Radiation Oncologist (Pending Referral)

questions.text: If I choose a Lumpectomy and SNLB, will I definitively need radiation therapy? If so, what is the goal of the radiation (e.g., reducing local recurrence)?
What is the typical course of treatment (e.g., 6 weeks of standard radiation, or a shorter course like hypofractionated), and how is that decision made?
What are the most common short-term side effects (skin changes, fatigue) and long-term risks (lung or heart exposure) associated with the specific radiation plan you would recommend for me?
What daily commitment does treatment require? Can I drive myself to and from my daily radiation appointments?
Does your center offer resources or support to help manage the fatigue that often comes with daily radiation?

fields.disclaimer: This decision aid helps you understand your medical information and prepare for doctor visits. It is not medical advice and does not replace talking with your healthcare team.
